**Understanding Zero-Value Day Vulnerabilities:**

Zero-value day vulnerabilities refer to a specific type of bug that occurs when a system's internal clock is set to January 1, 1970, also known as the "Year 2038 problem." This issue arises because many systems store timestamps as 32-bit integers, which can overflow and wrap around to a negative value when exceeding the maximum value of 2^31-1 (2147483647). When the clock rolls over to January 1, 1970, the system may malfunction or crash.
